text: Hi All - new here from more general value betting. Currently backtesting my first strategy and reading about the law of large numbers. Wondering if anyone could offer me their thoughts on what they would consider adequate backtesting? Currently testing with 400 cricket matches - c. 1500 matched bets, but this feels like not enough to overcome any variance.

elements.text: Hi All - new here from more general value betting. Currently backtesting my first strategy and reading about the law of large numbers. Wondering if anyone could offer me their thoughts on what they would consider adequate backtesting? Currently testing with 400 cricket matches - c. 1500 matched bets, but this feels like not enough to overcome any variance.

text: Depends exactly what markets you are betting on but most likely those 1500 are not independent so your effective sample size is the number of matches: 400. A suitable sample size will depend on the nature of the strategy (e.g. is it betting on favourites or longshots) but I agree, you probably want 10 or 100 times what you have in order to conclusively say whether you have something profitable. And that may be impossible given frequency (or lack thereof) of matches

elements.text: Depends exactly what markets you are betting on but most likely those 1500 are not independent so your effective sample size is the number of matches: 400. A suitable sample size will depend on the nature of the strategy (e.g. is it betting on favourites or longshots) but I agree, you probably want 10 or 100 times what you have in order to conclusively say whether you have something profitable. And that may be impossible given frequency (or lack thereof) of matches

text: My view on cricket is that T20s might be your best bet, and even then, your sample size is limited. But better than any other form

elements.text: My view on cricket is that T20s might be your best bet, and even then, your sample size is limited. But better than any other form

text: Cheers for your thoughts. Please could you expand on suitable sample sizes based on strategy? I hadn't really thought about the difference but my initial thought was that with only two runners the variance in betting on favourites/longshots would take the same amount of time to come out given the pairing of the odds, but that's just a guess really.

text: Lots of "trading". Have been watching it for the last couple of years. Franchise T20 is the target. If you have a really good model, you could make a lot of money. Data available is good. Matches are constrained. And if you look hard you might be able to get ball-by-ball for pretty much every franchise T20 match ever played. Would take some effort, but think what you could do with that!

elements.text: Lots of "trading". Have been watching it for the last couple of years. Franchise T20 is the target. If you have a really good model, you could make a lot of money. Data available is good. Matches are constrained. And if you look hard you might be able to get ball-by-ball for pretty much every franchise T20 match ever played. Would take some effort, but think what you could do with that!

text: Again, depends what you are doing exactly but rather than calculating the expected value empirically (by working out the realised profit), one way to dramatically reduce the required sample size is to use market prices you consider to be efficient to calculate the expected value directly. The most common example of this would be if you consider early market prices to contain value but the market to be efficient at the start of the match. This is the closing line value concept that American bettors love

elements.text: Again, depends what you are doing exactly but rather than calculating the expected value empirically (by working out the realised profit), one way to dramatically reduce the required sample size is to use market prices you consider to be efficient to calculate the expected value directly. The most common example of this would be if you consider early market prices to contain value but the market to be efficient at the start of the match. This is the closing line value concept that American bettors love

text: It looks like the number of places on the betfair exchange is different to the standard formula (2 places in a four horse race!?). What is the betfair number-of-places formula?

elements.text: It looks like the number of places on the betfair exchange is different to the standard formula (2 places in a four horse race!?). What is the betfair number-of-places formula?

text: based on declared, they don't reduce on NR's

elements.text: based on declared, they don't reduce on NR's

text:
```MARKET INFORMATION

For further information please see Rules & Regs.

Who will finish 1st or 2nd in this race? NON RUNNERS DO NOT CHANGE THE PLACE TERMS. Should the number of runners be equal to or less than the number of places available as set out above in these rules all bets will be void. Betfair Non-Runner Rule applies. This market will turn IN PLAY at the off with unmatched bets (with the exception of bets for which the "keep" option has been selected) cancelled once the Betfair SP reconciliation process has been completed. Betting will be suspended at the end of the race. This market will initially be settled on a First Past the Post basis. However we will re-settle all bets should the official result at the time of the "weigh-in" announcement differ from any initial settlement. BETS ARE PLACED ON A NAMED HORSE. Dead Heat rules apply.```

elements.text:
MARKET INFORMATION

For further information please see Rules & Regs.

Who will finish 1st or 2nd in this race? NON RUNNERS DO NOT CHANGE THE PLACE TERMS. Should the number of runners be equal to or less than the number of places available as set out above in these rules all bets will be void. Betfair Non-Runner Rule applies. This market will turn IN PLAY at the off with unmatched bets (with the exception of bets for which the "keep" option has been selected) cancelled once the Betfair SP reconciliation process has been completed. Betting will be suspended at the end of the race. This market will initially be settled on a First Past the Post basis. However we will re-settle all bets should the official result at the time of the "weigh-in" announcement differ from any initial settlement. BETS ARE PLACED ON A NAMED HORSE. Dead Heat rules apply.

text:
I know this has been asked before, but while waiting for <@U4H19D1D2> <@UGV299K6H> <@UBS7QANF3> , etc to actually start the "fundamentals" docs that have been discussed numerous times :grinning: , can anyone recommend any decent educational books? First steps into probability, statistics, regression, ML, data science, etc that a none-mathematician could learn from would be good start.
Personally, I have a basic understanding of probability because of my interest in gambling but have never formally studied maths beyond whatever we did at school 30+ years ago, most of which I've long forgotten. :joy:
